author: Mawich
title: Lifting the standard
review:
Of all the Lego Town sets I own this is easily one of my most treasured.  I had so much fun playing with this set as a kid because there was so much to this set. 

First and foremost, the spring loaded "jaws" were just so cool and great for picking up bricks and other things at construction sites.  The grey supports were a nice touch and a necessity because the crane would tip over without them if the arm was stretched too far forward.

This set was the second crane set released. 670/558 was the first but the crane was smaller in scale and the minifig couldn't fit inside.

A number of other cranes were released in subsequent years but 6678 was the only one with the distinctive "jaws".

A side note about this set is it was released a year before the introduction of the "pop up" vehicle roofs.  This explains why the crane has a rather cool "drop top" look to it.

author: CamberbrickGreen
title: Lift & Drop, Smash & Grab
review:
If you like construction, this is a great early 1980s set. One brick was almost left off the score only for the fact that other designs could bulk out the vehicle more but this is just nitpicking.

Minifigures:
  • Construction worker with black trousers, blue top and a red hard hat.
Do The Demolition
The bright yellow (of course) crane is a rotational chassis vehicle that has stabilisers attached at its sides while its load sits on four chunky wheels. The rear section represents an engine housing and makes a realistic overhang that balances its load bearing, 'business' end.

The driver's cab has black pneumatic control sticks with the steering wheel and chair that are protected by a black railed bar section with a brilliant yellow warning 'beacon' finishing the main section. It would be suitable that every construction worker comes with a mug of hot drink in their cab if not their hand?

The windscreen and lights are basic enough but the fun starts in front of this with the pneumatic arm that holds the thick black hinge that was a model changing brick of this age. Its socket brick ends the arm to hold a ball jointed giant yellow, spring-loaded bucket. Exciting beyond belief at the time but a component built alternative would probably be the current TFOL & AFOL preference. What quite inspired this brick is unknown because it certainly got used but also abused to lengths of car crushing, house wrecking, bank heists and provocatively grabbing anything that belonged to siblings. Suffice to say MFs can be a victim of such dangerous machinery.

Crushing The Competition
Despite the practical lifter-dropper capability of the crane, it seems to win out as more of a demolition set. The one piece brick term escapes me but the bucket also succeeds unusually because it worked so well. A fully built version would also be a welcome feature in future sets. A smashing success.
